(4) The API Landscape Lifecycle

  • Not about single APIs → It's about the API landscape
  • Lifecycle of evolving towards AI readiness
    1. Better API Description and Documentation [Better API Description and Documentation (1)]
    2. Smarter API Search and Selection [Smarter API Search and Selection (1)]
    3. Observing and Understanding API Usage [Observing and Understanding API Usage (1)]
    4. Designing Higher-Level Capabilities [Designing Higher-Level Capabilities (1)]
    5. Safe Experimentation with Sandboxes [Safe Experimentation with Sandboxes (1)]


Introduction: APIs for AI — Problem or Not? Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(5) Bridging the Gap Between API Land and AI Land

  • API landscapes are not AI-ready yet
  • Descriptions and designs often make AI difficult
  • Letting AI agents loose oftentimes is not an option
    • Limit blast radius: Only provide access through a centralized access point
    • Zero tolereance: Never allow access to production APIs
  • Use AI as little as possible and as much as necessary


Introduction: APIs for AI — Problem or Not? Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(6) (How) does AI affect APIs?



Introduction: APIs for AI — Problem or Not? Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(7) From DX to AX

  • APIs were typically consumed by developers
  • Developers write code that often fills API/UX gaps
  • AI takes the developer out of the picture
  • LLMs have much more limited context than developers

Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(9) Model Context Protocol (MCP)

  • MCP is the current standard protocol for LLM consumers
  • The initial focus was on additional and extended context
    • Additional context by providing access to the environment
    • Extended context by allowing MCP servers to externally manage context
  • Many mapping tools generate MCP servers from OpenAPI descriptions
  • What to expose and how to design it is out of scope


Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(10) MCP all the Things: Using MCP in 30min

  1. Generate MCP from OpenAPI
  2. Publish/Install MCP servers for all APIs
  3. Consumers can access all MCP tools


Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(11) MCP all the Things



Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(12) MCP all the Things: Simple but Limited

  • Pros:
    • Zero development effort, many tools auto-generate MCP
    • Every API operation immediately available
    • No maintenance of mapping layer
    • Great for early and quick experimentation
  • Cons:
    • Context window explosion with large APIs
    • AI struggles with understanding workflow across endpoints
    • Risk of misinterpreting MCP problems as general AI problems
    • API changes show up in MCP with unclear side-effects
  • Good as a starting point but lacks sophistication and scalability


Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(13) MCP Lego Kit: Manage Context Size

  1. Select required API capabilities
  2. Aggregate all tools in one MCP servers
  3. Consumers can access all required MCP tools


Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(14) MCP Lego Kit



Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(15) MCP Lego Kit: Small but still Granular

  • Pros:
    • Context size can be reduced
    • First step towards providing the right tools for the job
    • Useful as mitigation for further experimentation
  • Cons:
    • AI task/domain must be known in advance
    • Fine-granular APIs are still directly exposed
    • AI needs to re-invent workflows every single time
  • Show value with some simple tasks but get ready for more complex ones


Model Context Protocol (MCP) Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(20) Model Context Protocol (MCP)

  • Problem #1: Complex APIs will overload the MCP host's context
  • Problem #2: Larger API landscapes will overload the MCP host's context
  • Problem #3: Poor API design translates to poor MCP results
  • Problem #4: Bad AX results in unsatisfactory AI results


Better API Description and Documentation

Better API Description and Documentation Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(22) Do Your DX Homework

  • Most API descriptions need quality improvements anyway
  • Better descriptions benefit everyone, not just AI agents
    • Complete and meaningful operation summaries
    • Comprehensive examples for all operations
    • Clear error handling documentation
    • Consistent terminology and naming
  • Good DX is the foundation for good AX
  • Start with the basics: make your APIs understandable


Better API Description and Documentation Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(23) Now There's AX Homework Too

  • AI agents need information developers don't typically require:
    • Everything that developers usually just know
    • Treat every API like an external one for developers with no context
  • OpenAPI Initiative could add AX-specific fields
  • Until then, leverage description fields strategically
  • Consider AX surface area as a new design dimension


Better API Description and Documentation Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(24) The OpenAPI Initiative (OAI)

  • Today: no AX-specific fields in OpenAPI
  • Community needs to define what AI agents require
  • Tooling will follow once fields are standardized
  • Interested? Join the discussion in the OpenAPI Initiative

Smarter API Search and Selection Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(26) API Microproducts

  • Traditional API products bundle endpoints into coarse offerings
  • With unknown use cases, it's better to decompose into fine-grained API microproducts
    • OpenAPI: Treat all operations on all endpoints individual capabilities
    • AsyncAPI: Treat all messages on all channels as individual capabilities
    • GraphQL: Treat all queries and mutations as individual capabilities
  • Allows flexible combination of capabilities for any use case


Smarter API Search and Selection Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(27) Semantic Search with RAG

  • All capabilities indexed in a vector database
  • Queries resolved via semantic search (embeddings & similarity)
  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) assembles relevant operations
    • Retrieval: find the best matching capabilities
    • Augmentation: add retrieved capabilities into the agent's context
    • Generation: the agent plans or produces the sequence of API calls
  • Depends heavily on rich descriptions (garbage in, garbage out)

Observing and Understanding API Usage Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(29) Secure Centralized Access for Agents

  • Agents should have their own security regime
  • Avoid leaking secrets and tokens directly to agents
  • Prevent agents from impersonating users or apps
  • Ensure proper token delegation and downscoping
  • Route all traffic through a centralized access point
  • Clear separation: we always know when an agent acts


Observing and Understanding API Usage Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(30) Observability and Usage Mining

  • Centralized access gives visibility into all agent activity
  • Enables business process mining on API usage traces
  • Assess safety and compliance before allowing production use
  • Captured traces = foundation for designing higher-level workflows
  • Spot common patterns and emerging workflows
  • Captured traces = foundation for designing higher-level workflows

Designing Higher-Level Capabilities Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(32) Observing Agents to Discover Workflows

  • Agents try to solve tasks in their own way
  • We can observe their sequences of API calls
  • Observation in the wild or in a sandbox
  • Sandboxes allow safe experimentation without touching production
  • Captured traces reveal workflow candidates


Designing Higher-Level Capabilities Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(33) Workflows as Deterministic Artifacts

  • Extracted workflows become deterministic descriptions
  • Can be replayed and executed reliably
  • Enable review and auditing before adoption
  • More energy efficient than trial-and-error agent execution
  • Workflows can be published as new APIs, usable beyond AI


Safe Experimentation with Sandboxes

Safe Experimentation with Sandboxes Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(35) Sandboxes for Secure Experimentation

  • Create a controlled environment for agents
  • Make capabilities available in the sandbox
  • Prevent agents from accessing production secrets
  • Provide realistic data (synthetic or mock) for testing
  • Centralized control: we decide where agents can play


Safe Experimentation with Sandboxes Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(36) What's Your AI Risk Appetite?

  • Sandbox use = AI only for workflow discovery
  • No AI activity directly in production
  • Workflows validated before adoption
  • You decide how much AI to let into production
  • Architecture stays the same while risk level is adjustable

Conclusions Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide

(38) Evolving Your API Landscape for AI

  • Start simple: improve API descriptions and documentation
  • Build up: add search, observability, workflows, and sandboxes
  • End goal: a flexible landscape, safe for agents and valuable for everyone


Conclusions Erik Wilde: Your APIs Are Not Ready for AI (Yet): A Lifecycle-Based Readiness Guide
